SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.twilio4j.twism
Class TwilioParameters

java.lang.Object
  com.twilio4j.twism.TwilioParameters

public class TwilioParameters
extends java.lang.Object

TwilioParameters are passed to your action and callback handlers. They contain all of the standard Twilio parameters, documented here. It explains:

Twilio makes HTTP requests to your application just like a regular web browser. By including parameters and values in its requests, Twilio sends data to your application that you can act upon before responding. You can configure the URLs and HTTP Methods Twilio uses to make its requests via your account portal or using the REST API.

When Twilio receives a call for one of your Twilio numbers it makes a synchronous HTTP request to the Voice URL configured for that number, and expects to receive TwiML in response. Twilio sends the following parameters with its request as POST parameters or URL query parameters, depending on which HTTP method you've configured:

Author:
broc.seib@gentomi.com

getUserParams

public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> getUserParams()
Twilio4j maintains a HashMap of "user parameters", persisting it as a cookie to the twilio client. On subsequent interactions with your servlet, this set of userParams is passed to your action and callback handlers such that you can modify its state. It is in this manner that you should maintain state in your call flow. Of course you are limited by the 4k limit of a cookie, and there is some overhead in the escaping and encoding and digital signing of the userParams in cookie form. So if you for some reason need to keep more than ~2K of data, consider storing an opaque key in the userParams, and persisting the actual data elsewhere.

Returns:
the HashMap of userParams out of the cookie from the current caller.

getHttpParameters

public java.util.Map getHttpParameters()
Return the HttpRequest Parameter Map for debugging purposes.

Returns:
the Map of parameters from the HTTP request.

getCallSid

public java.lang.String getCallSid()
Returns:
A unique identifier for this call, generated by Twilio.

getAccountSid

public java.lang.String getAccountSid()
Returns:
Your Twilio account id. It is 34 characters long, and always starts with the letters AC.

getFrom

public java.lang.String getFrom()
Returns:
The phone number of the party that initiated the call. Formatted with a '+' and country code e.g., +16175551212 (E.164 format). If the call is inbound, then it is the caller's caller ID. If the call is outbound, i.e., initiated via a request to the REST API, then this is the phone number you specify as the caller ID.

getTo

public java.lang.String getTo()
Returns:
The phone number of the called party. Formatted with a '+' and country code e.g., +16175551212 (E.164 format). If the call is inbound, then it's your Twilio phone number. If the call is outbound, then it's the phone number you provided to call.

getCallStatus

public TwilioParameters.CallStatus getCallStatus()
Returns:
A descriptive status for the call. The value is one of queued, ringing, in-progress, completed, busy, failed or no-answer. These values are enumerated in TwilioParameters.CallStatus.

getApiVersion

public java.lang.String getApiVersion()
Returns:
The version of the Twilio API used to handle this call. For incoming calls, this is determined by the API version set on the called number. For outgoing calls, this is the API version used by the outgoing call's REST API request.

getDirection

public java.lang.String getDirection()
Returns:
Indicates the direction of the call. In most cases this will be inbound, but if you are using it will be outbound-dial.

getForwardedFrom

public java.lang.String getForwardedFrom()
Returns:
This parameter is set only when Twilio receives a forwarded call, but its value depends on the caller's carrier including information when forwarding. Not all carriers support passing this information.

getFromCity

public java.lang.String getFromCity()
Returns:
The city of the caller.

getFromState

public java.lang.String getFromState()
Returns:
The state or province of the caller.

getFromZip

public java.lang.String getFromZip()
Returns:
The postal code of the caller.

getFromCountry

public java.lang.String getFromCountry()
Returns:
The country of the caller.

getToCity

public java.lang.String getToCity()
Returns:
The city of the called party.

getToState

public java.lang.String getToState()
Returns:
The state or province of the called party.

getToZip

public java.lang.String getToZip()
Returns:
The postal code of the called party.

getToCountry

public java.lang.String getToCountry()
Returns:
The country of the called party.

getSmsSid

public java.lang.String getSmsSid()
Returns:
A 34 character unique identifier for the message. May be used to later retrieve this message from the REST API.

getBody

public java.lang.String getBody()
Returns:
The text body of the SMS message. Up to 160 characters long.

getCallDuration

public int getCallDuration()
CallDuration parameter is present in StatusCallback requests. After receiving a call, requesting TwiML from your app, processing it, and finally ending the call, Twilio will make an asynchronous HTTP request to the StatusCallback URL configured for the called Twilio number (if there is one). By providing a StatusCallback URL for your Twilio number and capturing this request you can determine when a call ends and receive information about the call.

Returns:
The duration in seconds of the just-completed call.
